Caesar: Caesar ciphers are trivial crack by brute force as there are only as many possible keys as alphabets and it is unlikely that an alphabet will contain more than a hundred characters.
Substitution: General substitution ciphers have a very large keyspace but are vulnerable to straighforward attack by computer. The hill climbing method attempts to build the correct key by repeatedly making small changes to a guess and accepting only changes that produce a more plausible text. Here the change is simply swapping the position of two ramdom characters in the alphabet.
